com.itko.lisaint

Class LisaCollector

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.lisaint.LisaCollector
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IReport
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CompInfo

    public abstract class LisaCollector
extends java.lang.Object
implements IReport
    This class is the abstract base class for all Lisa Integrator collection objects. It provides most of the information read/write methods.

    You will not use this class directly, but its method are critical to TransInfo and CompInfo.

      • assertFailTrans

        public void assertFailTrans(boolean expr)
        Provides a handy way for you to quickly make an assertion that LISA should consider this transaction failed if the following is not true. The build status code will be set to the failed code and a default build status message will be used.

        LISA will make the next node that is executed by the "error node" associated with the LISA Integration filter that is handling our test execution.

        Parameters:
        expr - - sets build status to failed if this expression is false

      • assertFailTrans

        public void assertFailTrans(boolean expr,
                   java.lang.String statusMsg)
        Provides a handy way for you to quickly make an assertion that LISA should consider this transaction failed if the following is not true. The build status code will be set to the failed code.

        LISA will make the next node that is executed by the "error node" associated with the LISA Integration filter that is handling our test execution.

        Parameters:
        expr - - sets build status to failed if this expression is false
        statusMsg - - build status message if bad

      • addLogMessage

        public void addLogMessage(java.lang.String loggerName,
                 java.lang.String level,
                 java.lang.String message)
        Take note of a server-side log message. It will be transmitted back to LISA so you can see what's going on inside your test case

      • addLoggedSql

        public java.lang.String addLoggedSql(LoggedSql loggedSql)

      • addSql

        public java.lang.String addSql(java.sql.Statement statement,
                      java.lang.String prepared,
                      java.lang.String sql,
                      long elapsed)
        Called by the LisaJdbcDriver each time a SQL is issued. You almost certainly should not call this method, use the LisaJdbcDriver to wrap your data source instead.

        The set of unique SQLs is kept until the transaction context is closed and they are sent back to LISA as part of the integrator payload. Each unique SQL is given an ID. The intent is to allow QE's to look at the unique SQLs involved in a use case and make sure the WHERE clauses are using table indexes on large tables. In the future, LISA may even parse the queries and issue a warning if a query uses a non-indexed field in a WHERE or ORDER BY clause. We also keep track of the number of invocations of the SQL and the average response time (individual response times are also instrumented per invocation)

        Best practice is to use prepared statements in your app, so the number of unique SQLs will probably be quite low; if you are seeing lots of unique SQLs without '?' placeholders in the query then your app is most likely not using prepared statments and will therefore be slower than it needs to be..

        Parameters:
        prepared - the prepared statement as a string with '?' for parameter placeholders
        sql - the actual SQL issued with real values instead of placeholders
        elapsed - How long did this SQL take?
        Returns:
        The SQL ID for the statement

      • addSql

        public java.lang.String addSql(java.lang.String connectionInfo,
                      java.sql.Statement statement,
                      java.lang.String prepared,
                      java.lang.String sql,
                      long elapsed)

      • addBatch

        public java.lang.String addBatch(java.sql.Statement statement,
                        java.lang.String prepared,
                        java.lang.String sql,
                        long execTimeMillis)
        Called by the LisaJdbcDriver each time a batch is added to a JDBC statement. You almost certainly should not call this method, use the LisaJdbcDriver to wrap your data source instead.

        Batching is used by many apps and object-relational frameworks such as Hibernate. Batching greatly increases performance by reducing the number of network round trips to the database.

        Parameters:
        prepared - the prepared statement as a string with '?' for parameter placeholders
        sql - the actual SQL issued with real values instead of placeholders
        execTimeMillis - How long did this SQL take?
        Returns:
        The SQL ID for the statement

      • addBatch

        public java.lang.String addBatch(java.lang.String connectionInfo,
                        java.sql.Statement statement,
                        java.lang.String prepared,
                        java.lang.String sql,
                        long execTimeMillis)

      • resultSetNext

        public void resultSetNext(java.sql.Statement statement,
                 java.sql.ResultSet rs,
                 java.lang.String rowAsString)
        Take note of the fact that we have iterated over a ResultSet. The row data will go back to LISA if we are integrated and we also keep track of the total number of rows we have pulled from result sets; this will give us some insight into inefficent querys, for example iterating over an entire table on the server instead of contructing the SQL such that the database does the heavy lifting.
        Parameters:
        rowAsString - the string representation of the row

      • addEjbEvent

        Add an ejb event. Currently called be the internal EJB3 interceptor machinery on bean method invocations and EJB3 entity lifecycle events.
        Parameters:
        event -

      • assertLog

        public void assertLog(boolean expr,
             java.lang.String logMsg)
        Provides the server component author with a mechansim to validate an assertion and log a message into the test event collection system within Lisa if the given assertion is false.
        Parameters:
        expr - expression that if false will cause Lisa to be given a log message
        logMsg - the log message to report if the assertion is false

      • finished

        public void finished()
        Tells us we've completed processing this component, and takes defaults for all end-status kinds of things.

        Components "know" if they have already been finished(), so you can call this method as many times as you like to ensure that the components are completing as needed.

        Repeated reqeusts to finished() are ignored. Only the first call matters.

      • finished

        public void finished(java.lang.String buildStatus,
            java.lang.String buildMsg,
            java.lang.Throwable tw,
            java.lang.String content)
        This method is called when the compnent (trans or comp) is finished processing.
        Parameters:
        buildStatus - send null for this class to query child components and take the worst as its status. For example, if a child set its status to F, then this build status would be F. If there are no children or none are set to anything interesting (!S or !U), then we'll use S for this status.
        buildMsg - if the status message has not already been set, we'll set it to this
        tw - if the isn't already an Exception registered for this comp, then we'll use this one
        content - if you have some to share, or null if you don't.

      • getChildren

        public java.util.List<CompInfo> getChildren()

        Returns:

      • setBuildStatus

        public void setBuildStatus(java.lang.String status,
                  java.lang.String statusMsg)
        Enables the system under test to declare its execution or build status to Lisa explicitly. Valid values are constants here and include:

        • S - STATUS_SUCCESS - when the component executed as expected
        • U - STATUS_UNKNOWN - if the status is not determinable
        • R - STATUS_REDIRECT - when the component issued a redirect (only valid for some systems)
        • I - STATUS_INPUTERROR - when the component failed due to bad inputs
        • E - STATUS_EXTERNALERROR - when the component failed due to external resource errors
        • F - STATUS_FAILED - when the component failed, presumably not because inputs or extenal resources

        Note: IEF are all generally considered fail codes on the Lisa side

        Parameters:
        status - the code as described above
        statusMsg - the message to provide detail or explanation to the test case author

      • getBuildStatusMsg

      • isTransFailed

        public boolean isTransFailed()
        Useful on the LISA side to determine this simply
        Returns:
        true if the build status is a fail code

      • getBuildTime

        public long getBuildTime()
        Returns the component execution time in milliseconds.

        The build time is determined by calculating the time between this objects creation and when finished() was called for the first time. The build time is -1 if the component has not yet been finished(). You can explicitly set the build time with setBuildTime()

        Returns:
        the build time for this component in milliseconds

      • setBuildTime

        public void setBuildTime(long millis)
        Deprecated. Will be removed in a future release.
        Enables the server component author to explicitly set the build time of this component. This step is not required. Build time will be determined when the finished() method is called.
        Parameters:
        millis - how long the component execution took in milliseconds

      • setCompContent

        public void setCompContent(java.lang.String content)
        This is how a component can set its content to report to the Lisa. For HTML-type applications, this can simply be the HTML generated. For others, it might be more tricky...

        The Integrator has methods to turn on or off the reporting of this content, so don't waste a bunch of cycles doing so if Integrator.isLogCompContent() false...

        Parameters:
        content - the content to report to the test case

      • getCompContent

        public java.lang.String getCompContent()
        Will return the component content for this component, or null if none was provided.

        The Filter can be invoked on the test case side with a flag to determine if Lisa even wants component content.

        Returns:
        the component content reported, or null

      • log

        public void log(java.lang.String msg)
        To raise an EVENT_NODEMSG event on the LISA side with the given message in the long info field
        Parameters:
        msg - what you wish to log

      • sendLISATestEvent

        public void sendLISATestEvent(int evID,
                     java.lang.String shortDesc,
                     java.lang.String longDesc)
        Any Lisa test event can be sent via this mechanism. Generally, LOG messages are the safest ones, and any custom Event ID can obviously be used.

        Unless filtered, all test even listeners on the Lisa execution side of the test will receive any event provided here. This creates a very powerful way for the server component author to document important information into the testing side of Lisa.

        For example, if a component was developed to a spec that specifically scoped out a certain feature or condition, but a test case was attempting to invoke that feature or condition, a test event could be generated to notify the test case author.

        Parameters:
        evID - - the event ID that should match those in the com.itko.lisa.test.TestEvent class or be a custom event ID
        shortDesc - - the short description that will be logged
        longDesc - - the long description that will be logged

      • getLISATestEvents

        public java.util.List getLISATestEvents()
        Returns a List of the test events set by this component, or null if there weren't any

      • setException

        public void setException(java.lang.Throwable tw)
        Components can explicitly declare that an exception was caught during its processing and report that exception to Lisa by calling this method. Lisa test case authors can vary the test case execution and reporting based on whether and what exception might have been thrown.

        Note that this does not set a build status code! Also note that if you provide an exception to the finished() method it will be ignored if you have already called this one. Lisa only keeps a single possible exception record per component.

        Parameters:
        tw - the exception that was caught

      • getException

        public ExceptionInfo getException()
        Returns an ExceptionInfo object that wraps an exception that was reported by the system under test for this component, or null if there was not one reported.

      • getExceptionList

        public java.util.List<ExceptionInfo> getExceptionList()

      • setLISAProp

        public void setLISAProp(java.lang.String key,
               java.io.Serializable val)
        A simple wrapper for setLISAProp(String, Object)
        Parameters:
        key -
        val -

      • setLISAProp

        public void setLISAProp(java.lang.String key,
               java.lang.Object val)
        Server component authors have the ability to set Properties on the Lisa test execution that is running them. This is a very powerful mechanism to use for making server components fully test-enabled and test cases very robust.

        Any token that would otherwise have to be parsed from the servers output should instead be explicitly defined here. That will dramatically improve the ability of the testing to succeed.

        For very advanced users that are extending Lisa on the test case side of the architecture, any Java object can be sent to Lisa. The object is encoded with XStream (http://xstream.codehaus.org) and decoded on the fly when needed.

        Parameters:
        key - the key that Lisa will use to look up the given value. Any current value with the same key will be replaced, so make sure this key is properly scoped. Often people use the package name or project name as a prefix to all key names.
        val - the value you want Lisa to store in the TestExec object calling us

      • getLISAProps

        public java.util.List getLISAProps()
        Returns the set of Lisa property set requests that the server component has requested, or null if there were none.

      • notifyContentMissing

        public void notifyContentMissing(java.lang.String contKey)
        Content-based applications can use this mechanism to report that a peice of content was missing. This application-defined content key will be added to a list of missing keys that are reported to Lisa.

        Test case authors can vary execution based on whether content was missing for this component. The JPL does this automatically, but Servlet and other applications can leverage this too.

        Parameters:
        contKey - the content key that was missing

      • getMissingContent

        public java.util.List getMissingContent()
        Returns a List of content keys that were reported missing by the system under test Elements of this collection are of the java.lang.String type.

      • notifyContentUsed

        public void notifyContentUsed(java.lang.String contKey)
        This method enables server component authors to declare what content keys were used in constructing the result given. This is used for content-based applications like servlets or the JPL
        Parameters:
        contKey - the content key used in construction of the output

      • getContentUsed

        public java.util.List getContentUsed()
        Returns a List of content keys that were reportedly used by the system under test Elements of this collection are of the java.lang.String type.

      • notifyPropUsed

        public void notifyPropUsed(java.lang.String propKey,
                  java.lang.Object propValue)
        This provides a mechanism for system component authors to declare what session state variables were used during processing. This maps very well for JPL or servlet application domains.
        Parameters:
        propKey - the session key accessed
        propValue - the value at the time it was used

      • getPropsUsed

        public java.util.List getPropsUsed()
        Returns a List of the properties that were reportedly used during processing of this component. This List's elements are of the type com.itko.lisaint.LisaProp
        Returns:
        a List of LisaProp objects

      • notifyPropMissing

        public void notifyPropMissing(java.lang.Object propKey)
        Enables system under test authors to declare that a needed property was not in session state during processing of this component. This maps well for servlet or JPL applications that maintain session state.
        Parameters:
        propKey - the key for the object that was expected but missing

      • getPropsMissing

        public java.util.List getPropsMissing()
        Returns a List of the properties that were reported missing during the processing of this component. The Elements of this List are of the type java.lang.String and are the property keys missing.
